intro: Leontodon hispidulus, commonly known as the hairy leopard's bread, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the daisy family (Asteraceae) and is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and yellow-orange flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, grassy habitats and is often found in meadows and rocky areas. Its flowering period occurs in late summer to early autumn, and it produces small, wind-dispersed seeds. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
